title: Pharyngitis
text:
Pharyngitis is <a href="inflammation">inflammation</a> of the back of the <a href="throat">throat</a>, known as the <a href="pharynx">pharynx</a>. It typically results in a <a href="sore%20throat">sore throat</a> and <a href="fever">fever</a>. Other symptoms may include a <a href="Rhinorrhea">runny nose</a>, <a href="cough">cough</a>, <a href="headache">headache</a>, difficulty swallowing, swollen lymph nodes, and a <a href="hoarse%20voice">hoarse voice</a>. Symptoms usually last 3–5 days. Complications can include <a href="sinusitis">sinusitis</a> and <a href="acute%20otitis%20media">acute otitis media</a>. Pharyngitis is a type of <a href="upper%20respiratory%20tract%20infection">upper respiratory tract infection</a>.
Most cases are caused by a <a href="viral%20infection">viral infection</a>. <a href="Strep%20throat">Strep throat</a>, a bacterial infection, is the cause in about 25% of children and 10% of adults. Uncommon causes include other bacteria such as <a href="gonorrhea">gonorrhea</a>, <a href="fungus">fungus</a>, irritants such as smoke, <a href="allergies">allergies</a>, and <a href="gastroesophageal%20reflux%20disease">gastroesophageal reflux disease</a>. Specific testing is not recommended in people who have clear symptoms of a viral infection, such as a <a href="common%20cold">cold</a>. Otherwise, a <a href="rapid%20antigen%20detection%20test">rapid antigen detection test</a> (RADT) or <a href="throat%20swab">throat swab</a> is recommended. Other conditions that can produce similar symptoms include <a href="epiglottitis">epiglottitis</a>, <a href="thyroiditis">thyroiditis</a>, <a href="retropharyngeal%20abscess">retropharyngeal abscess</a>, and occasionally <a href="heart%20disease">heart disease</a>.
<a href="NSAIDs">NSAIDs</a>, such as <a href="ibuprofen">ibuprofen</a>, can be used to help with the pain. Numbing medication, such as topical <a href="lidocaine">lidocaine</a>, may also help. Strep throat is typically treated with <a href="antibiotic">antibiotic</a>s, such as either <a href="penicillin">penicillin</a> or <a href="amoxicillin">amoxicillin</a>. It is unclear whether <a href="corticosteroids">steroids</a> are useful in acute pharyngitis, other than possibly in severe cases, but a recent (2020) review found that when used in combination with antibiotics they moderately improved pain and the likelihood of resolution.
About 7.5% of people have a sore throat in any 3-month period. Two or three episodes in a year are not uncommon. This resulted in 15 million physician visits in the United States in 2007. Pharyngitis is the most common cause of a sore throat. The word comes from the <a href="Classical%20language">Greek word</a> "pharynx" meaning "throat" and the suffix "-itis" meaning "inflammation".
Classification.
Pharyngitis is a type of inflammation caused by an <a href="upper%20respiratory%20tract%20infection">upper respiratory tract infection</a>. It may be classified as acute or chronic. Acute pharyngitis may be <a href="catarrh">catarrh</a>al, <a href="purulent">purulent</a>, or <a href="Ulcer%20%28dermatology%29">ulcerative</a>, depending on the <a href="causative%20agent">causative agent</a> and the <a href="Immunity%20%28medical%29">immune capacity</a> of the affected individual. Chronic pharyngitis may be catarrhal, <a href="Hypertrophy">hypertrophic</a>, or <a href="Atrophy">atrophic</a>.
<a href="Tonsillitis">Tonsillitis</a> is a subtype of pharyngitis. If the inflammation includes both the <a href="tonsil">tonsil</a>s and other parts of the throat, it may be called pharyngotonsillitis or tonsillopharyngitis. Another subclassification is <a href="nasopharyngitis">nasopharyngitis</a> (the common cold).
Cause.
Most cases are due to an <a href="infectious%20organism">infectious organism</a> acquired from close contact with an infected individual.
Viral.
These comprise about 40–80% of all infectious cases and can be a feature of many different types of viral infections.
Bacterial.
A number of different bacteria can infect the human throat. The most common is <a href="group%20A%20streptococcus">group A streptococcus</a> ("Streptococcus pyogenes"), but others include "<a href="Streptococcus%20pneumoniae">Streptococcus pneumoniae</a>", "<a href="Haemophilus%20influenzae">Haemophilus influenzae</a>", "<a href="Bordetella%20pertussis">Bordetella pertussis</a>", "<a href="Bacillus%20anthracis">Bacillus anthracis</a>", "<a href="Corynebacterium%20diphtheriae">Corynebacterium diphtheriae</a>", "<a href="Neisseria%20gonorrhoeae">Neisseria gonorrhoeae</a>", "<a href="Chlamydophila%20pneumoniae">Chlamydophila pneumoniae</a>", "<a href="Mycoplasma%20pneumoniae">Mycoplasma pneumoniae</a>," and "<a href="Fusobacterium%20necrophorum">Fusobacterium necrophorum</a>".
Streptococcal pharyngitis or strep throat is caused by a <a href="group%20A%20beta-hemolytic%20streptococcus">group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus</a> (GAS). It is the most common bacterial cause of cases of pharyngitis (15–30%). Common symptoms include <a href="fever">fever</a>, <a href="sore%20throat">sore throat</a>, and large lymph nodes. It is a contagious infection, spread by close contact with an infected individual. A definitive diagnosis is made based on the results of a <a href="throat%20culture">throat culture</a>. <a href="Antibiotics">Antibiotics</a> are useful to both prevent complications (such as <a href="rheumatic%20fever">rheumatic fever</a>) and speed recovery.
"<a href="Fusobacterium%20necrophorum">Fusobacterium necrophorum</a>" is a normal inhabitant of the oropharyngeal <a href="Bacterial%20flora">flora</a> and can occasionally create a <a href="peritonsillar%20abscess">peritonsillar abscess</a>. In one out of 400 untreated cases, <a href="Lemierre%27s%20syndrome">Lemierre's syndrome</a> occurs.
<a href="Diphtheria">Diphtheria</a> is a potentially life-threatening upper respiratory infection caused by "<a href="Corynebacterium%20diphtheriae">Corynebacterium diphtheriae</a>", which has been largely eradicated in developed nations since the introduction of childhood <a href="vaccination">vaccination</a> programs, but is still reported in the <a href="Third%20World">Third World</a> and increasingly in some areas in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. Antibiotics are effective in the early stages, but recovery is generally slow.
A few other causes are rare, but possibly fatal, and include <a href="parapharyngeal%20space">parapharyngeal space</a> infections: <a href="peritonsillar%20abscess">peritonsillar abscess</a> ("quinsy abscess"), <a href="submandibular%20space%20infection">submandibular space infection</a> (Ludwig's angina), and <a href="epiglottitis">epiglottitis</a>.
Fungal.
Some cases of pharyngitis are caused by <a href="Fungal%20infection%20in%20animals">fungal infection</a>, such as "<a href="Candida%20albicans">Candida albicans</a>", causing <a href="Oral%20candidiasis">oral thrush</a>.
Noninfectious.
Pharyngitis may also be caused by mechanical, chemical, or thermal irritation, for example cold air or <a href="acid%20reflux">acid reflux</a>. Some medications may produce pharyngitis, such as <a href="pramipexole">pramipexole</a> and <a href="antipsychotic">antipsychotic</a>s.
Diagnosis.
Differentiating a viral and a bacterial cause of a sore throat based on symptoms alone is difficult. Thus, a <a href="throat%20swab">throat swab</a> often is done to rule out a bacterial cause.
The modified <a href="Centor%20criteria">Centor criteria</a> may be used to determine the management of people with pharyngitis. Based on five clinical criteria, it indicates the probability of a streptococcal infection.
One point is given for each of the criteria:
The <a href="Infectious%20Disease%20Society%20of%20America">Infectious Disease Society of America</a> recommends against <a href="empirical%20treatment">empirical treatment</a> and considers antibiotics only appropriate following positive testing. Testing is not needed in children under three, as both group A strep and <a href="rheumatic%20fever">rheumatic fever</a> are rare, except if they have a sibling with the disease.
Management.
The majority of the time, treatment is symptomatic. Specific treatments are effective for bacterial, fungal, and <a href="herpes%20simplex">herpes simplex</a> infections.
Alternative.
Gargling <a href="salt%20water">salt water</a> is often suggested, but there is no evidence to support or discourage this practice. <a href="Alternative%20medicines">Alternative medicines</a> are promoted and used for the treatment of sore throats. However, they are poorly supported by evidence.
Epidemiology.
Acute pharyngitis is the most common cause of a <a href="sore%20throat">sore throat</a> and, together with cough, it is diagnosed in more than 1.9 million people a year in the United States.
